title: A Bad Word on TV at Awards Show
summary: At the Bafta Film Awards on TV, a person with Tourette's syndrome shouted a mean word about race. This happened while two black actors were on stage. Many people got upset because the word was hurtful. The BBC, which showed the awards, said it was a big mistake. They are checking what happened quickly. Lisa Nandy, a government leader, talked to the BBC boss and said this must not happen again. She wants award shows to be nice places for everyone, including people with Tourette's. The BBC is doing an investigation to make sure this never happens again.

background_read: The Bafta Film Awards are a special event where movies and actors get prizes. Sometimes, things go wrong on TV, like when someone says something bad. In this case, a person with Tourette's syndrome, which makes them say things they don't mean, shouted a racial slur, which is a very hurtful word about race. This upset many people, especially because it happened while black actors were on stage. The BBC, which broadcast the show, is checking what happened to make sure it doesn't happen again. Lisa Nandy is a leader in the government who helps make rules about culture and TV shows.
Article_Structure: WHO: Lisa Nandy, the BBC, a person with Tourette's syndrome, and black actors Michael B Jordan and Delroy Lindo
WHAT: A racial slur was shouted at the Bafta Film Awards on TV, causing upset and an investigation
WHERE: At the Bafta Film Awards in the UK, broadcast by the BBC
WHY: To address the harm caused and ensure it doesn't happen again, making award shows inclusive for all

perspectives.description: Lisa Nandy says the incident was unacceptable and demands action from the BBC to prevent future issues.
